question: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive development of tender breast tissue over the past 18 months. He used to ride his bicycle for exercise 4 times a week but stopped after he had an accident and injured his left testicle 3 months ago. He has gained 5 kg (11 lb) during this period. For the last 10 years, he drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. He occasionally takes pantoprazole for heartburn. He is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia. A nontender 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left testis; transillumination test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

content.source_1: This 32-year-old man presents with gynecomastia, which is the development of breast tissue in males. There are several factors to consider in this patient's history that could contribute to gynecomastia. First, he has gained weight, and obesity is known to be associated with gynecomastia due to increased conversion of androgens to estrogens in adipose tissue. Second, the patient has been consuming alcohol, and alcohol can increase aromatization of androgens to estrogens. Third, the patient has a mass in the left testicle, which could potentially be a tumor affecting the hormonal balance. The history of trauma to the testicle and the finding of a non-transilluminating mass is highly suggestive of a testicular tumor. Testicular tumors, especially Leydig cell tumors, can produce estrogen leading to gynecomastia.
content.source_2: The patient presents with bilateral gynecomastia, which can be caused by an imbalance of the hormones estrogen and testosterone. There are several factors to consider in this patient's case that could be contributing to this hormonal imbalance. Firstly, the patient has gained weight and has a BMI indicative of obesity. Adipose tissue can convert androgens into estrogens, which can lead to increased levels of circulating estrogen. Additionally, his alcohol consumption can also play a role. Chronic alcohol use is known to decrease testosterone levels and increase the conversion of androgens to estrogens in the liver. Another important factor in this case is the testicular injury he had 3 months ago. The presence of a non-tender mass in the left testis with a negative transillumination test suggests that it could be a testicular tumor. Testicular tumors can secrete human chorionic gonadotropin, which can stimulate breast tissue and cause gynecomastia. In this scenario, the combination of obesity, alcohol use, and a possible testicular tumor could be contributing to the hormonal imbalance leading to the development of gynecomastia.
